intro: Boehmeria platyphylla var. zeylanica, commonly known as silky fibers or silk cotton, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the nettle family, Urticaceae, and is characterized by its soft, silky fibers that are harvested from the stems. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 3 meters. Its leaves are large, heart-shaped, and have a velvety texture, while the flowers are small and inconspicuous. The fibers of this plant have been traditionally used in textiles and papermaking due to their fine, soft quality.
